title: What's your theme song? If your life was a TV series what would you choose as the opening song? - Quora

response.answer_text: I spent a lot of time thinking about this. I thought about having some of my all time favorites, amazing songs like Nothing Else Matters- Metallica, or Sweet Child O’ Mine- Guns N' Roses, or even Helter Skelter- The Beatles. Just real classics that I have and will always love. But then I realized that though those songs are amazing, they're not really me at all. Then I thought about using a song that actually emotionally helped me like Hey Jude-The Beatles, Built This Way-Samantha Rosum, or I'm With You- Avril Lavigne. But then I realized though these are empowering songs, I don't at all want them to describe my life. After that I thought about focusing on something about me, and I love air guitarring to songs in my bedroom, I do it everyday, so I thought about Smells Like Teen Spirit, Mr. Brightside, and I Was Made for Lovin’ You- KISS. I mean it's a part of my life, a huge part of it, and as a tv show would focus in about my life, it should have been perfect! Right? Something didn't feel right, and I had an epiphany, I needed a song that was built into the core of me, a song that I grew up listening to. That was the perfect criteria and I found two perfect songs, that would be a sin for me to choose between. Both are also themselves theme songs: I Found a Way and Leave it All to Me. If you don't know what tv shows they belong to or who sang them then I just cannot talk to you, don't comment asking what they are, just go in a dark corner, preferably with spiders and cobwebs, and rethink your life choices (But if you're older than 30 I guess I can forgive you). For those of you teenagers and millenials who do know it, you probably grew up with these songs as well. Leave it all to me has the perfect lyrics and I Found a Way has the perfect beat (okay not perfect but cut them some slack, it's a kids tv show it can't be The Beatles level perfect). These were the roots of my childhood, and I cannot imagine two other songs that could represent me in a better way.

At my age, one song just ain’t enough—so… Here is the compilation CD…and the short explanations why the song fits. They are in no particular order.. Percolator—Spyro Gyra—coffee is the principal thing, therefore coffeeSlow and Easy—Mancini—The Music of Peter Gun—get uptight and things get fucked upTake Five—Brubeck Quartet—Think things throughForever in Blue Jeans—Neil Diamond—what I wear pretty much all the timeMove—Miles Davis Nonet-from Birth of the Cool—Do not stop-always learn, always seek, always care…always move on…even if it is one day at a timeHarlem Nocturne—just about any version—we all get down…this song helps me soarMaui—Hawaiian Suppa Man—Israel Kamakawiwo'ole—this song, sung by this singer, is the absolutely best cure to get you out of the deepest funkBirdland—Weather Report—Just fucking great soundsSoul Food To Go—Manhattan Transfer—Our souls need to be fed—and jazz feeds mine.You Make (Let) Me Be So Very Happy—BS&T—I do modify the song title just a bit…no person can MAKE another person happy…they can give them the room to express their inner joy…and my beloved DB, whom it took my my lifetime so far to find…allows me that freedom…and I thank her for that every day.That’s it..for now. I may return to round out the list to an even dozen. This, however, should give you an idea what I’ve gathered in the musical idiom to make it to this point; not survive, mind you, to grow and be one with myself and those around me. Namaste
